values.description:
Ported selection buffer from ogre v1, which is needed for mouse picking. The implementation is different from v1 due to  API changes and a v1 feature that’s no longer supported in ogre so I had to implement my own.  

The ogre2 demo has been extended to print out the visual being selected by the mouse.

More details:

Mouse picking is done by assigning a unique color to each visual. At run time, the pixel picked by the mouse will then be used to identify the visual associated with that pixel color. This was achieved using ogre “material schemes” in ogre v1, which switches visual materials to their unique color during a mouse click. However, it’s no longer supported in v2 and I had to implement my own logic in Ogre2MaterialSwitcher class \(in pre and posRenderTargetUpdate functions\) for doing this. I added a note about performance profiling in there as switching ogre materials could be expensive in v2. Since we don’t do it often \(only on mouse clicks\) I think it’s fine for now but will keep an eye on it.
values.title: Ogre2: Support mouse picking

summary.raw:
Ported selection buffer from ogre v1, which is needed for mouse picking. The implementation is different from v1 due to  API changes and a v1 feature that’s no longer supported in ogre so I had to implement my own.  

The ogre2 demo has been extended to print out the visual being selected by the mouse.

More details:

Mouse picking is done by assigning a unique color to each visual. At run time, the pixel picked by the mouse will then be used to identify the visual associated with that pixel color. This was achieved using ogre “material schemes” in ogre v1, which switches visual materials to their unique color during a mouse click. However, it’s no longer supported in v2 and I had to implement my own logic in Ogre2MaterialSwitcher class \(in pre and posRenderTargetUpdate functions\) for doing this. I added a note about performance profiling in there as switching ogre materials could be expensive in v2. Since we don’t do it often \(only on mouse clicks\) I think it’s fine for now but will keep an eye on it.
summary.html:
Ported selection buffer from ogre v1, which is needed for mouse picking. The implementation is different from v1 due to API changes and a v1 feature that’s no longer supported in ogre so I had to implement my own.

The ogre2 demo has been extended to print out the visual being selected by the mouse.

More details:

Mouse picking is done by assigning a unique color to each visual. At run time, the pixel picked by the mouse will then be used to identify the visual associated with that pixel color. This was achieved using ogre “material schemes” in ogre v1, which switches visual materials to their unique color during a mouse click. However, it’s no longer supported in v2 and I had to implement my own logic in Ogre2MaterialSwitcher class (in pre and posRenderTargetUpdate functions) for doing this. I added a note about performance profiling in there as switching ogre materials could be expensive in v2. Since we don’t do it often (only on mouse clicks) I think it’s fine for now but will keep an eye on it.

values.description:
Addresses [this](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/issues/35/scene3d-memory-leak-on-resize) Ignition GUI issue when resizing the window.

This PR improves the situation, but I can still see some leak.

Commenting out the call to `this->RebuildViewport` fixes the leak, so I think it's something there. It seems that we're creating a new `ogreViewport` every time, but I'd expect that removing the previous target and removing all viewports of the new target should take care of this?
values.title: Improve target rebuilding

summary.raw:
Addresses [this](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/issues/35/scene3d-memory-leak-on-resize) Ignition GUI issue when resizing the window.

This PR improves the situation, but I can still see some leak.

Commenting out the call to `this->RebuildViewport` fixes the leak, so I think it's something there. It seems that we're creating a new `ogreViewport` every time, but I'd expect that removing the previous target and removing all viewports of the new target should take care of this?
summary.html:
Addresses this Ignition GUI issue when resizing the window.

This PR improves the situation, but I can still see some leak.

Commenting out the call to this->RebuildViewport fixes the leak, so I think it's something there. It seems that we're creating a new ogreViewport every time, but I'd expect that removing the previous target and removing all viewports of the new target should take care of this?

values.description:
from this [post](https://forums.ogre3d.org/viewtopic.php?t=92111#p535220), ogre depth buffers are not cleared when a render texture is removed so we need to explicitly call a function to clean them up 

It works in ogre1 but not ogre2
values.title: Fix Ogre render target memory leak

values.description:
Added support for roughness, metalness, and environment maps in materials. You can also set roughness and metalness values directly without.

Updated ogre2\_demo to include a pump mesh that uses PBR textures and a box that has an environment map. Also tweaked the red sphere to give a glossy metallic appearance. Note: you’ll need the collada fixes in [this ign-common PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/152/colladaloader-fixes/diff) to load the pump mesh.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/3244575173-ogre2_demo_pbr.png)
values.title: Ogre2: Add support for PBR maps

summary.raw:
Added support for roughness, metalness, and environment maps in materials. You can also set roughness and metalness values directly without.

Updated ogre2\_demo to include a pump mesh that uses PBR textures and a box that has an environment map. Also tweaked the red sphere to give a glossy metallic appearance. Note: you’ll need the collada fixes in [this ign-common PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/152/colladaloader-fixes/diff) to load the pump mesh.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/3244575173-ogre2_demo_pbr.png)
summary.html:
Added support for roughness, metalness, and environment maps in materials. You can also set roughness and metalness values directly without.

Updated ogre2_demo to include a pump mesh that uses PBR textures and a box that has an environment map. Also tweaked the red sphere to give a glossy metallic appearance. Note: you’ll need the collada fixes in this ign-common PR to load the pump mesh.

values.description:
Various`Destroy*` functions in Scene have been extended to include an optional arg that lets user destroy nodes recursively. By default it’s false.

Note the difference between `Remove*` and `Destroy*`.  ‘Remove' detaches the node from the tree while ’Destroy' deletes the node \(and detaches its children if recursive is set to false\)
values.title: Add functions to recursively destroy a node and its children

summary.raw:
Various`Destroy*` functions in Scene have been extended to include an optional arg that lets user destroy nodes recursively. By default it’s false.

Note the difference between `Remove*` and `Destroy*`.  ‘Remove' detaches the node from the tree while ’Destroy' deletes the node \(and detaches its children if recursive is set to false\)
summary.html:
VariousDestroy* functions in Scene have been extended to include an optional arg that lets user destroy nodes recursively. By default it’s false.

Note the difference between Remove* and Destroy*. ‘Remove' detaches the node from the tree while ’Destroy' deletes the node (and detaches its children if recursive is set to false)

values.description:
Switched to use ign-plugin \(from ign-comon’s PluginLoader\) as it supports unloading plugin libraries. An engine plugin can now be unloaded by calling:

`ignition::rendering::unloadEngine(engineName)`

Updated all tests so that rendering engine is now unloaded and reloaded between each test case.  While doing this, I had to make some changes to make sure ogre objects are cleaned up properly on shutdown. 

This is a step towards running ogre and ogre2 tests one after another.
values.title: Use ign-plugin and support unloading rendering engine plugin libraries

summary.raw:
Switched to use ign-plugin \(from ign-comon’s PluginLoader\) as it supports unloading plugin libraries. An engine plugin can now be unloaded by calling:

`ignition::rendering::unloadEngine(engineName)`

Updated all tests so that rendering engine is now unloaded and reloaded between each test case.  While doing this, I had to make some changes to make sure ogre objects are cleaned up properly on shutdown. 

This is a step towards running ogre and ogre2 tests one after another.
summary.html:
Switched to use ign-plugin (from ign-comon’s PluginLoader) as it supports unloading plugin libraries. An engine plugin can now be unloaded by calling:

ignition::rendering::unloadEngine(engineName)

Updated all tests so that rendering engine is now unloaded and reloaded between each test case. While doing this, I had to make some changes to make sure ogre objects are cleaned up properly on shutdown.

This is a step towards running ogre and ogre2 tests one after another.

There is still one problem with the tests when ogre1 and ogre2 are both installed, see issue #36

values.description:
Depends on pull request #113, pull request #114, and pull request #115. Please review those first

Fixes memory leaks when repeatedly creating and deleting visuals, materials, and meshes. Included in this PR is a performance test, `test/performance/scene_factory.cc`, that checks the memory usage before and after running a piece of code that creates and destroy objects.

With the help of [heaptrack](https://github.com/KDE/heaptrack) and it's `heaptrack_gui` visualization tool \(thanks to @azeey for the recommendation\), I was able to identify possible places of leaks and verify that they are fixed.

Here are a few memory consumption graphs for the two performance tests in `scene_factory.cc`

**ogre1.x**

MaterialMemoryLeak test - memory consumption stays roughly constant after 5000 creations and deletions

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/3868236620-heaptrack_scene_materials.png)
‌

VisualMemoryLeak test - visuals are created and deleted in batches hence the wave like pattern.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/3984210993-heaptrack_scene_visuals.png)
‌

**ogre2.x** \(higher overall memory usage could be because it’s installed from source in debug build\)

MaterialMemoryLeak test

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/754718843-heaptrack_material_ogre2.png)
‌

VisualMemoryLeak test

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/826907701-heaptrack_visual_ogre2.png)
values.title: Fix memory leaks

Depends on pull request #113, pull request #114, and pull request #115. Please review those first

Fixes memory leaks when repeatedly creating and deleting visuals, materials, and meshes. Included in this PR is a performance test, test/performance/scene_factory.cc, that checks the memory usage before and after running a piece of code that creates and destroy objects.

With the help of heaptrack and it's heaptrack_gui visualization tool (thanks to @azeey for the recommendation), I was able to identify possible places of leaks and verify that they are fixed.

Here are a few memory consumption graphs for the two performance tests in scene_factory.cc

ogre1.x

MaterialMemoryLeak test - memory consumption stays roughly constant after 5000 creations and deletions

‌

VisualMemoryLeak test - visuals are created and deleted in batches hence the wave like pattern.

‌

ogre2.x (higher overall memory usage could be because it’s installed from source in debug build)

MaterialMemoryLeak test

‌

VisualMemoryLeak test

values.description:
Fixes an issue where the direction vector of an ogre2 directional light is overridden when its pose is set. Fixed by creating an intermediate node to hold the internal ogre2 light object so that the correct transform is applied to the direction vector.

Added a Light unit test that catches this issue.
values.title: Fix ogre2 light direction when pose changes

summary.raw:
Fixes an issue where the direction vector of an ogre2 directional light is overridden when its pose is set. Fixed by creating an intermediate node to hold the internal ogre2 light object so that the correct transform is applied to the direction vector.

Added a Light unit test that catches this issue.
summary.html:
Fixes an issue where the direction vector of an ogre2 directional light is overridden when its pose is set. Fixed by creating an intermediate node to hold the internal ogre2 light object so that the correct transform is applied to the direction vector.

Added a Light unit test that catches this issue.

values.description:
depends on [ign-cmake pull request 122](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/122/update-findogre2-to-work-with-new-debs/diff)

The changes should allow ign-rendering to find and build both ogre and ogre2 plugins. 

Note that ogre1.x and ogre2.x can not be loaded at the same time due to symbol collision. So running `make test` will only run `ogre` and `optix` tests. 

To run `ogre2` tests, do:

`RENDER_ENGINE_VALUES=ogre2 make test`
values.title: Work with new ogre2 debs

summary.raw:
depends on [ign-cmake pull request 122](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/122/update-findogre2-to-work-with-new-debs/diff)

The changes should allow ign-rendering to find and build both ogre and ogre2 plugins. 

Note that ogre1.x and ogre2.x can not be loaded at the same time due to symbol collision. So running `make test` will only run `ogre` and `optix` tests. 

To run `ogre2` tests, do:

`RENDER_ENGINE_VALUES=ogre2 make test`
summary.html:
depends on ign-cmake pull request 122

The changes should allow ign-rendering to find and build both ogre and ogre2 plugins.

Note that ogre1.x and ogre2.x can not be loaded at the same time due to symbol collision. So running make test will only run ogre and optix tests.

To run ogre2 tests, do:

RENDER_ENGINE_VALUES=ogre2 make test

values.description:
Added ogre2 implementation of gpu rays.

Similar to the 2 pass approach in the ogre1.x, the idea is to get depth data in the 1st pass and compute the correct range value for each ray in the sensor in the 2nd pass. The implementation is quite different. In the ogre2 implementation, we use 2 compositor workspaces for rendering to texture, i.e. one for each pass. The 1st pass creates a cubemap of depth data \(more specifically they are converted to viewspace ‘range’ values\), and the 2nd pass samples these range values from the cubemap using rays.

Note that the downside of sampling from depth buffer is [precision](https://www.khronos.org/opengl/wiki/Depth_Buffer_Precision), which is affected by the near/far clip planes \(min/max range settings\). So objects far away \(close to far clip plane\) may suffer from less accurate readings.

To run ogre2 tests from build directory:

`RENDER_ENGINE_VALUES=ogre2 make test`
values.title: Add Ogre2GpuRays sensor

summary.raw:
Added ogre2 implementation of gpu rays.

Similar to the 2 pass approach in the ogre1.x, the idea is to get depth data in the 1st pass and compute the correct range value for each ray in the sensor in the 2nd pass. The implementation is quite different. In the ogre2 implementation, we use 2 compositor workspaces for rendering to texture, i.e. one for each pass. The 1st pass creates a cubemap of depth data \(more specifically they are converted to viewspace ‘range’ values\), and the 2nd pass samples these range values from the cubemap using rays.

Note that the downside of sampling from depth buffer is [precision](https://www.khronos.org/opengl/wiki/Depth_Buffer_Precision), which is affected by the near/far clip planes \(min/max range settings\). So objects far away \(close to far clip plane\) may suffer from less accurate readings.

To run ogre2 tests from build directory:

`RENDER_ENGINE_VALUES=ogre2 make test`
summary.html:
Added ogre2 implementation of gpu rays.

Similar to the 2 pass approach in the ogre1.x, the idea is to get depth data in the 1st pass and compute the correct range value for each ray in the sensor in the 2nd pass. The implementation is quite different. In the ogre2 implementation, we use 2 compositor workspaces for rendering to texture, i.e. one for each pass. The 1st pass creates a cubemap of depth data (more specifically they are converted to viewspace ‘range’ values), and the 2nd pass samples these range values from the cubemap using rays.

Note that the downside of sampling from depth buffer is precision, which is affected by the near/far clip planes (min/max range settings). So objects far away (close to far clip plane) may suffer from less accurate readings.

To run ogre2 tests from build directory:

RENDER_ENGINE_VALUES=ogre2 make test

values.description:
issue #41

The files generated by ogre2 material system are actually [debug outputs](https://forums.ogre3d.org/viewtopic.php?t=93750) and not really needed. So updated to disable writing them to disk.
values.title: Disable writing ogre2 material system debug shaders to disk

summary.raw:
issue #41

The files generated by ogre2 material system are actually [debug outputs](https://forums.ogre3d.org/viewtopic.php?t=93750) and not really needed. So updated to disable writing them to disk.
summary.html:
issue #41

The files generated by ogre2 material system are actually debug outputs and not really needed. So updated to disable writing them to disk.

values.description: Problem was identified in this [ign-gui pull request](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/182/gz11-support-for-levels-add-and-remove/diff) where repeatedly adding and removing visuals results in a segfault. This was caused by removal of visual geometry materials when a visual is deleted but that particular material was still being referenced by ogre’s real time shader systems. The solution is to clean up the real time shader system when a geometry is removed.
values.title: Fix repeatedly adding and removing visuals in ogre1.x

summary.raw: Problem was identified in this [ign-gui pull request](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/182/gz11-support-for-levels-add-and-remove/diff) where repeatedly adding and removing visuals results in a segfault. This was caused by removal of visual geometry materials when a visual is deleted but that particular material was still being referenced by ogre’s real time shader systems. The solution is to clean up the real time shader system when a geometry is removed.
summary.html: Problem was identified in this ign-gui pull request where repeatedly adding and removing visuals results in a segfault. This was caused by removal of visual geometry materials when a visual is deleted but that particular material was still being referenced by ogre’s real time shader systems. The solution is to clean up the real time shader system when a geometry is removed.

values.description:
This PR includes a Depth Camera class for ogre2 and a test used with ogre 1.9 and ogre 2.1.

You can use it with:

    RENDER_ENGINE_VALUES=ogre2 ./bin/INTEGRATION_depth_camera

Point cloud data output for depth data is missing, for now the output is a depth image. I will add it asap in another PR.
values.title: Add depth camera class to Ogre2

Point cloud data output for depth data is missing, for now the output is a depth image. I will add it asap in another PR.

values.description:
Couple of fixes:

* Plugins \(in the form of dll\) are stored in the binary directory when compiled on Windows. 
* Ogre plugins need to have the dll extension on Windows

This solves the #issue 40 although the tests are still crashing. 

![](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ign_rendering-pr-win&build=173)
[https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign\_rendering-pr-win/173/](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_rendering-pr-win/173/))

Windows displays \(both on Jenkins and local\) the error: ` unknown file: error: SEH exception with code 0xc0000005 thrown in the test body.` I've verified that it happens during the call `RenderEngine *engine = rendering::engine(_renderEngine);` when using ogre so probably something is not working well on ogre plugins loading.
values.title: Fix Windows plugins paths

summary.raw:
Couple of fixes:

* Plugins \(in the form of dll\) are stored in the binary directory when compiled on Windows. 
* Ogre plugins need to have the dll extension on Windows

This solves the #issue 40 although the tests are still crashing. 

![](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ign_rendering-pr-win&build=173)
[https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign\_rendering-pr-win/173/](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_rendering-pr-win/173/))

Windows displays \(both on Jenkins and local\) the error: ` unknown file: error: SEH exception with code 0xc0000005 thrown in the test body.` I've verified that it happens during the call `RenderEngine *engine = rendering::engine(_renderEngine);` when using ogre so probably something is not working well on ogre plugins loading.
summary.html:
Couple of fixes:

  • Plugins (in the form of dll) are stored in the binary directory when compiled on Windows.
  • Ogre plugins need to have the dll extension on Windows

This solves the #issue 40 although the tests are still crashing.

https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ign_rendering-pr-win/173/)

Windows displays (both on Jenkins and local) the error: unknown file: error: SEH exception with code 0xc0000005 thrown in the test body. I've verified that it happens during the call RenderEngine *engine = rendering::engine(_renderEngine); when using ogre so probably something is not working well on ogre plugins loading.

values.description:
lights that do not cast shadows are assumed to use more advanced techniques in ogre 2.1 \(e.g. Forward3D or ForwardClustered\) and need to be explicitly enabled, see this [ogre post](https://forums.ogre3d.org/viewtopic.php?t=94229).

Without this change, non-shadow-casting point lights and spot lights will just be disabled. 

Added a non-shadow-casting spot light to ogre2\_demo. The image below shows the scene before \(left\) and after \(right\) the fix. The spot light is completely disabled \(left\) when clustered forward rendering is not enabled.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/950416229-ogre_forward_compare.png)
values.title: Fix non-shadow-casting point lights and spot lights in ogre2

summary.raw:
lights that do not cast shadows are assumed to use more advanced techniques in ogre 2.1 \(e.g. Forward3D or ForwardClustered\) and need to be explicitly enabled, see this [ogre post](https://forums.ogre3d.org/viewtopic.php?t=94229).

Without this change, non-shadow-casting point lights and spot lights will just be disabled. 

Added a non-shadow-casting spot light to ogre2\_demo. The image below shows the scene before \(left\) and after \(right\) the fix. The spot light is completely disabled \(left\) when clustered forward rendering is not enabled.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/950416229-ogre_forward_compare.png)
summary.html:
lights that do not cast shadows are assumed to use more advanced techniques in ogre 2.1 (e.g. Forward3D or ForwardClustered) and need to be explicitly enabled, see this ogre post.

Without this change, non-shadow-casting point lights and spot lights will just be disabled.

Added a non-shadow-casting spot light to ogre2_demo. The image below shows the scene before (left) and after (right) the fix. The spot light is completely disabled (left) when clustered forward rendering is not enabled.

values.description:
Tested using `xvfb` in ubuntu bionic. Note ogre2 needs min opengl version of 3.3\+ but the version reported when run under xvfb is 3.0 \(see [this post](https://askubuntu.com/questions/850900/why-is-my-opengl-version-stuck-at-3-0-despite-new-hardware-software) for more info\) so we need to manually override the driver version by setting `MESA_GL_VERSION_OVERRIDE=3.3`. See changes in bitbucket-pipelines on how to run the tests headless

I had to make 2 fixes:

1. ported fix from this [gazebo pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2442/check-fsaa-support-when-creating-camera/diff) so that we don’t set anti-aliasing to levels that are not supported
2. mouse picking / selection buffer - testing under xvfb helped catch a precision error in object’s rgb values. Also updated the glsl shaders to version 330
values.title: Support running rendering tests headless

summary.raw:
Tested using `xvfb` in ubuntu bionic. Note ogre2 needs min opengl version of 3.3\+ but the version reported when run under xvfb is 3.0 \(see [this post](https://askubuntu.com/questions/850900/why-is-my-opengl-version-stuck-at-3-0-despite-new-hardware-software) for more info\) so we need to manually override the driver version by setting `MESA_GL_VERSION_OVERRIDE=3.3`. See changes in bitbucket-pipelines on how to run the tests headless

I had to make 2 fixes:

1. ported fix from this [gazebo pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2442/check-fsaa-support-when-creating-camera/diff) so that we don’t set anti-aliasing to levels that are not supported
2. mouse picking / selection buffer - testing under xvfb helped catch a precision error in object’s rgb values. Also updated the glsl shaders to version 330
summary.html:
Tested using xvfb in ubuntu bionic. Note ogre2 needs min opengl version of 3.3+ but the version reported when run under xvfb is 3.0 (see this post for more info) so we need to manually override the driver version by setting MESA_GL_VERSION_OVERRIDE=3.3. See changes in bitbucket-pipelines on how to run the tests headless

I had to make 2 fixes:

  1. ported fix from this gazebo pull request so that we don’t set anti-aliasing to levels that are not supported
  2. mouse picking / selection buffer - testing under xvfb helped catch a precision error in object’s rgb values. Also updated the glsl shaders to version 330

values.description: Install resources to `IGN_DATA_INSTALL_DIR` to prevent multiple directories from being created in `share`. Currently rendering creates one directory for tag files and one for resources.
values.title: Use IGN_DATA_INSTALL_DIR

summary.html: Install resources to IGN_DATA_INSTALL_DIR to prevent multiple directories from being created in share. Currently rendering creates one directory for tag files and one for resources.

values.description: pull request #140 added support for tests to be run headless. However, it’s been flaky on pipelines, e.g. this [build](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/969) ran fine but some tests failed in the subsequent [build](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/969). So disabling them for now to reduce noise in pipelines.
values.title: Disable tests on pipelines

summary.raw: pull request #140 added support for tests to be run headless. However, it’s been flaky on pipelines, e.g. this [build](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/969) ran fine but some tests failed in the subsequent [build](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/969). So disabling them for now to reduce noise in pipelines.
summary.html: pull request #140 added support for tests to be run headless. However, it’s been flaky on pipelines, e.g. this build ran fine but some tests failed in the subsequent build. So disabling them for now to reduce noise in pipelines.

values.description:
The private class should not be in the public header file.

The class did not have a `IGNITION_RENDERING_OGRE_VISIBLE` macro so not sure if this breaks ABI or not but targeted to `default` just in case.
values.title: Move OgreDepthCameraPrivate class to src file
